episodes.summary: There are millions of snakebite victims per year, but antivenom hasn't really changed since its development over 100 years ago. A doctor goes to extremes to find a solution.

episodes.title: #950: Overrated Or Underrated?

episodes.summary: Tyler Cowen rates the NBA, Karl Marx, Adam Smith, the humanities, your neighbors, and more.

episodes.title: #777: Free Love, Free Market

episodes.summary: Canada has put a price on pollution. The economist behind the idea thought about it more than a century ago.

episodes.title: #948: A Series Of Unfortunate Recessions
episodes.description: A Halloween journey into the economists' worst nightmare, an endless time loop of recession after recession after... | Subscribe to our weekly newsletter here.
episodes.subtitle: There is one real-life economic monster that can take away your money, your job, and your future: A recession.
episodes.summary: There is one real-life economic monster that can take away your money, your job, and your future: A recession.

episodes.title: #947: Some-of-the-Money Ball

episodes.subtitle: Baseball is a winner-take-all career path. But income pools could change the way baseball players, and other people in high risk/high reward professions, think about uncertainty.
episodes.summary: Baseball is a winner-take-all career path. But income pools could change the way baseball players, and other people in high risk/high reward professions, think about uncertainty.

episodes.title: #946: Fries Of The Future

episodes.subtitle: The modern french fry isn't just crispy and delicious, it's a technological marvel.
episodes.summary: The modern french fry isn't just crispy and delicious, it's a technological marvel.

episodes.title: #945: The Liberty City
episodes.description: A man in Texas had a dream: To build a whole new kind of city, with no property tax, no debt, and a whole lot of freedom. | Subscribe to our weekly newsletter here.
episodes.subtitle: Von Ormy, Texas is a small city with a big dream: To thrive with almost no regulations, property taxes, or debt.
episodes.summary: Von Ormy, Texas is a small city with a big dream: To thrive with almost no regulations, property taxes, or debt.

episodes.title: #753: Blockchain Gang
episodes.description: Charlie Shrem went from living in his parents' basement, to bitcoin millionaire, to federal prison in just a few years. | Subscribe to our weekly newsletter here.

episodes.summary: Charlie Shrem's odyssey in and out of prison is a parable for everything that has happened with bitcoin during its first years: from idealists to outlaws to respectable citizens.

episodes.title: #944: We Should Have Mentioned That

episodes.summary: We answer some of the most popular questions our listeners had after listening to our recent shows: on baseball cards, the repo market, and the least common American.

episodes.title: #763: BOTUS

episodes.summary: The Volfefe Index measures how much the President's tweets affect volatility in the bond market. In 2017, we launched our own investing project based on the President's tweets.

episodes.summary: Masayoshi Son raised the biggest venture capital fund in the history of the world, made WeWork possible, and radically changed the way startups work.

episodes.title: #942: Capitalism In The Courtroom
episodes.description: Investors can fund lawsuits for profit, which gives more people access to the courts. But some worry it will warp the justice system. | Subscribe to our weekly newsletter here.

episodes.title: #941: Three Bets
episodes.description: We jog to New Jersey to bet on tennis, we solve a mystery in Las Vegas, and we venture into the world of video game loot. | Subscribe to our weekly newsletter here.
episodes.subtitle: Planet Money takes a gamble on three stories about bets gone... every which way.
episodes.summary: Planet Money takes a gamble on three stories about bets gone... every which way.

episodes.title: #770: When India's Cash Disappeared
episodes.description: When India suddenly got rid of most of its cash, in an effort to end corruption and modernize its economy, chaos ensued. | Subscribe to our weekly newsletter here.
episodes.summary: When India suddenly got rid of most of its cash, in an effort to end corruption and modernize its economy, chaos ensued. | Subscribe to our weekly newsletter here.

episodes.title: #940: Interest Rates... Why So Negative?
episodes.description: All over the world, interest rates are very, very low. In some places, they're negative: you lend out money, and get less back. | Subscribe to our weekly newsletter here.
episodes.subtitle: Interest rates are low and getting lower. Some are even negative. Which means we live in a weird world, where people are lending out money and getting back less.
episodes.summary: Interest rates are low and getting lower. Some are even negative. Which means we live in a weird world, where people are lending out money and getting back less.

episodes.title: #658: Strike One
episodes.description: Strikes these days are pretty boring. But they weren't always like this. In the past, strikers risked their lives. | Subscribe to our weekly newsletter here.
episodes.subtitle: An automakers' strike against General Motors in the 1930s changed the world of unions forever. Before, striking was dangerous and illegal. Today, it's a fairly civilized business.
episodes.summary: An automakers' strike against General Motors in the 1930s changed the world of unions forever. Before, striking was dangerous and illegal. Today, it's a fairly civilized business.

episodes.title: #939: The Working Tapes Of Studs Terkel
episodes.description: Hear what ordinary people told Studs Terkel about their jobs in the 70s — and what they have to say now. | Subscribe to our weekly newsletter here.
episodes.subtitle: In the 1970s, Studs Terkel interviewed scores of people about their jobs for his book Working. Today, we hear a few of those conversations — and follow up with the subjects.
episodes.summary: In the 1970s, Studs Terkel interviewed scores of people about their jobs for his book Working. Today, we hear a few of those conversations — and follow up with the subjects.

episodes.title: #794: How To Make It In The Music Business
episodes.description: The hidden economy of producers buying and selling sonic snippets, texting each other beats, and angling for royalties. | Subscribe to our weekly newsletter here.
episodes.subtitle: Behind popular music, there is this hidden economy of music producers buying and selling sonic snippets, texting each other half-finished beats, and angling for back-end royalties.
episodes.summary: Behind popular music, there is this hidden economy of music producers buying and selling sonic snippets, texting each other half-finished beats, and angling for back-end royalties.

episodes.title: #938: The Marshall Plan
episodes.description: Sometimes the way to help yourself is to help your enemy. After WWII, the U.S. launched what might be the most successful intervention in history, rebuilding Germany and also the rest of Western Europe. | Subscribe to our weekly newsletter here.
episodes.subtitle: Sometimes to help yourself, you help your enemy. After WWII, the U.S. launched what might be the most successful intervention in history, rebuilding Germany and more.

episodes.title: #371: Where Dollar Bills Come From

episodes.subtitle: Imagine being the company that makes all the world's dollar bills. We found that company and took a look inside.
episodes.summary: Imagine being the company that makes all the world's dollar bills. We found that company and took a look inside.

episodes.title: #937: Moving To Opportunity?
episodes.description: In the 90s, the government ran an experiment: What happens if we move people out of high-poverty neighborhoods and into low-poverty ones? Housing policy as hope? The results surprised them. | Subscribe to our weekly newsletter here.

episodes.summary: In the 1990s, the government ran an experiment to test the economic impact of moving people to lower-poverty neighborhoods. The results surprised them.

episodes.title: #936: The Modal American
episodes.description: Kenny takes Jacob on a nerdy quest to find the "typical American." Naturally, it ends up harder⁠—and nerdier⁠—than we planned, and the answer is more subtle than we expected. | Subscribe to our newsletter here.
episodes.subtitle: Who is the average American? Bad question. You end up with a clumpy amalgamation of qualities. If you want to know how real people are living, you want the Modal American.
episodes.summary: Who is the average American? Bad question. You end up with a clumpy amalgamation of qualities. If you want to know how real people are living, you want the Modal American.

episodes.title: 935: You Asked For A Food Show
episodes.description: The top producer of Top Chef helps us spice up this food edition of listener questions. How do you master the salad bar? Why do Americans refrigerate eggs? The story of Choco Pies and more. | Subscribe to our weekly newsletter here.
episodes.subtitle: How to get the best value from the salad bar? Why do Americans refrigerate their eggs? What's the deal with Choco Pies? It's the food edition of listener questions.
episodes.summary: How to get the best value from the salad bar? Why do Americans refrigerate their eggs? What's the deal with Choco Pies? It's the food edition of listener questions.

episodes.title: #934: Two Yield Curve Indicators
episodes.description: An inverted yield curve has predicted recessions for the past six decades. The curve is inverted right now. What does that tell us? | Subscribe to our newsletter here.
episodes.subtitle: A 13-year-old listener wrote in asking if the inverted yield curve means that a recession is on the way. Today on the show, we try to answer him.
episodes.summary: A 13-year-old listener wrote in asking if the inverted yield curve means that a recession is on the way. Today on the show, we try to answer him.

episodes.title: #933: Find The Helium
episodes.description: Helium is so special, and so rare, that the U.S. government once tried to buy it all up. And hide it. But the government's helium stockpile is running low. And we need it for MRI machines and NASA rockets.
episodes.subtitle: You need helium to launch rockets into space. It's also essential for MRI machines and cellphones. But the world is running short on helium. So we're going looking for more.
episodes.summary: You need helium to launch rockets into space. It's also essential for MRI machines and cellphones. But the world is running short on helium. So we're going looking for more.

episodes.title: #616: How Solar Got Cheap
episodes.description: For a long time, only rich people could afford to put solar panels on the roof. Not anymore. Here's what changed.
episodes.subtitle: Solar energy used to be a fantasy. Then it arrived, but was too expensive for most people to afford. Now it's cheap. Here's how it happened.
episodes.summary: Solar energy used to be a fantasy. Then it arrived, but was too expensive for most people to afford. Now it's cheap. Here's how it happened.

episodes.title: #932: Deep Learning With The Elephants
episodes.description: Elephants are in danger. Counting them is crucial to saving them. But they're hard to see in the rainforest. So scientists are enlisting the help of AI technology.
episodes.subtitle: Counting elephants is key to saving them. But in the rainforest, they're hard to spot. One scientist is listening for them instead, with the help of artificial intelligence.
episodes.summary: Counting elephants is key to saving them. But in the rainforest, they're hard to spot. One scientist is listening for them instead, with the help of artificial intelligence.

episodes.title: #931: The IT Guy Vs. The Con Artist
episodes.description: A notorious con artist offered Felipe an IT job. He took the job —and tried to con the con man. | Plus, listen to a full double feature all about cons here.
episodes.subtitle: Felipe was an IT professional looking for a new gig. Then a notorious con artist offered him a job. Felipe took the job — and tried to con the con man.
episodes.summary: Felipe was an IT professional looking for a new gig. Then a notorious con artist offered him a job. Felipe took the job — and tried to con the con man.

episodes.title: #930: Twins
episodes.description: Scientists have studied twins for years, hoping to figure out how big a role genes play in human behavior. Our very own pair of twin reporters are on the case.
episodes.subtitle: Scientists have been studying twins for a long time, trying to figure out how much of human behavior is influenced by the environment, and how much of it is in our genes.
episodes.summary: Scientists have been studying twins for a long time, trying to figure out how much of human behavior is influenced by the environment, and how much of it is in our genes.

episodes.title: #598: That Time We Shorted America, Part Two
episodes.description: Everyone said betting against the entire stock market was a terrible idea. We did it anyway. Today, we find out the results, and revisit the first short ever done in the 17th century.

episodes.summary: We shorted America, taking a bet against its entire stock market. Today, we find out the results, and revisit the very first person to short a stock back in the 17th century.

episodes.title: #597: That Time We Shorted America, Part One
episodes.description: Today on the show, we ignore the advice of some very smart people and bet against something people love.
episodes.subtitle: Today on the show, we ignore the advice of some very smart people and bet against something people love.
episodes.summary: Today on the show, we ignore the advice of some very smart people and bet against something people love.

episodes.title: #929: Could A Wealth Tax Work?
episodes.description: Elizabeth Warren wants to tax the wealth of the mega-rich to help fix inequality. Europe tried this, and failed. Can it work in the U.S.?
episodes.subtitle: Elizabeth Warren wants to tackle inequality by taxing the wealth of the mega-rich ($50-million-or-more rich). Wealth taxes failed in Europe. Can they work in the U.S.?
episodes.summary: Elizabeth Warren wants to tackle inequality by taxing the wealth of the mega-rich ($50-million-or-more rich). Wealth taxes failed in Europe. Can they work in the U.S.?

episodes.title: #928: Hong Kong
episodes.description: In 1960, a 12-year-old boy left mainland China, hidden in the bottom of a fishing boat. He later became one of Hong Kong's richest people. His story is the story of Hong Kong.
episodes.subtitle: The Hong Kong protests tap into a complex history between China and the West. It's a story of isolationism, opium wars, and the rise of capitalism.
episodes.summary: The Hong Kong protests tap into a complex history between China and the West. It's a story of isolationism, opium wars, and the rise of capitalism.

episodes.title: #927: The Indicator In The House
episodes.description:
Two highlights from our daily podcast, The Indicator, about houses. A plan to lower rents pits state against city, and a private firefighter breaks down his business for us.
| Subscribe to our weekly newsletter here.
episodes.subtitle: One state, two very different stories: Why Huntington Beach won't build new homes during a housing shortage, and what private firefighters say about their industry and inequality.
episodes.summary: One state, two very different stories: Why Huntington Beach won't build new homes during a housing shortage, and what private firefighters say about their industry and inequality.

episodes.title: #926: So, Should We Recycle?
episodes.description: Cities might be picking up your recyclables, but there is a very good chance they aren't being recycled. And that might be a good thing...if you really care about the planet. Part two of a two-part series. ⎸Subscribe to our newsletter here.
episodes.subtitle: Recycling in America is on life support. Some towns aren't even picking it up anymore. And it might be a good thing for the planet.
episodes.summary: Recycling in America is on life support. Some towns aren't even picking it up anymore. And it might be a good thing for the planet.

episodes.title: #925: A Mob Boss, A Garbage Boat and Why We Recycle
episodes.description: In 1987, an Alabama man had an idea. So he made a deal with the mob. And ended up with 3,186 tons of trash no landfill would take. This is the accidental birth of recycling in the U.S. ⎸Subscribe to our newsletter here.
episodes.subtitle: In 1987, an Alabama man made a deal with the mob. He ended up with 3,186 tons of trash no landfill would take. It was the accidental birth of recycling in the U.S.
episodes.summary: In 1987, an Alabama man made a deal with the mob. He ended up with 3,186 tons of trash no landfill would take. It was the accidental birth of recycling in the U.S.

episodes.title: #924: Stuck In China's Panopticon
episodes.description: China is building a high-tech surveillance state to capture minorities' every move and word. We go inside it and find that some Americans are involved. Subscribe to our weekly newsletter npr.org/planetmoneynewsletter
episodes.subtitle: The Chinese government is using face recognition, DNA samples and more to track the Uighur population. Americans — some unknowingly — have helped build this surveillance state.
episodes.summary: The Chinese government is using face recognition, DNA samples and more to track the Uighur population. Americans — some unknowingly — have helped build this surveillance state.

episodes.title: #752: Eagles vs. Chickens
episodes.description: A farmer in Georgia became more in tune with nature. Then eagles started killing his chickens. Subscribe to our weekly newsletter: npr.org/planetmoneynewsletter
episodes.subtitle: Picture an organic farm, with thousands of free-range chickens roaming on open land. Now picture it from the vantage of a soaring bald eagle. It's an all-you-can-eat buffet.
episodes.summary: Picture an organic farm, with thousands of free-range chickens roaming on open land. Now picture it from the vantage of a soaring bald eagle. It's an all-you-can-eat buffet.

episodes.title: #923: Good Teachers, Bad Deal
episodes.description: Teachers made a deal with the Department of Education. They kept their end of the bargain. Why didn't the government?
episodes.subtitle: Thousands of teachers got grants from the Department of Education to help pay for college. Then, some of those same teachers found out they owed thousands of dollars in debt.
episodes.summary: Thousands of teachers got grants from the Department of Education to help pay for college. Then, some of those same teachers found out they owed thousands of dollars in debt.

episodes.title: #922: The Cost of Getting Your Money Back
episodes.description: Accidentally sending $1,500 to a stranger on Venmo reveals just how hard it is to get your money back in the new economy.
episodes.subtitle: It's easy to reverse transactions on credit cards. But Venmo is a different story. A woman who accidentally sent $1,500 to a complete stranger found this out the hard way.
episodes.summary: It's easy to reverse transactions on credit cards. But Venmo is a different story. A woman who accidentally sent $1,500 to a complete stranger found this out the hard way.

episodes.title: #921: Tales From The Parking Lot
episodes.description: Three stories: A tire-booting vigilante, a surge price conspiracy, and the civil rights fight over parking tickets.
episodes.subtitle: What can you do when your car is booted in a private parking lot? Is that even legal? Can Uber drivers cause surge pricing? When do parking tickets become a civil rights issue?
episodes.summary: What can you do when your car is booted in a private parking lot? Is that even legal? Can Uber drivers cause surge pricing? When do parking tickets become a civil rights issue?

episodes.title: #920: What Should We Be Worried About?
episodes.description: The economic recovery turns 10 this month. Don't get too comfortable. There's plenty to be worried about.
episodes.subtitle: Things are looking up in the economy, but there's still plenty to worry about: Corporate debt, the trade war, and worry itself.
episodes.summary: Things are looking up in the economy, but there's still plenty to worry about: Corporate debt, the trade war, and worry itself.

episodes.title: #919: Are Cities Overrated?
episodes.description: Big cities used to be the land of opportunity for most people. But with changes in work, some economists are wondering: Are cities overrated?
episodes.subtitle: Moving to the big city used to provide an escalator to a more prosperous life, even if you didn't have a college degree. But now economists are wondering: Are cities overrated?
episodes.summary: Moving to the big city used to provide an escalator to a more prosperous life, even if you didn't have a college degree. But now economists are wondering: Are cities overrated?

episodes.title: #590: The Planet Money Workout
episodes.description: Gyms don't want you to workout. Or at least, not often. It's better for business that way. Economics explains why.
episodes.subtitle: Barely workout? Gyms like it that way. They're one of a few businesses that benefit from low attendance. Economics explains why gyms encourage members to commit, but not too much.
episodes.summary: Barely workout? Gyms like it that way. They're one of a few businesses that benefit from low attendance. Economics explains why gyms encourage members to commit, but not too much.

episodes.title: #918: The Day Of Two Noons
episodes.description: People didn't always know what time it was. But in the nineteenth century, a high school principal, a scientist, and a railroad bureaucrat synchronized the nation.
episodes.subtitle: In the 1800s, every town had its own "local time," which was not only confusing, but sometimes dangerous. So railroads implemented the standardized time we have today.
episodes.summary: In the 1800s, every town had its own "local time," which was not only confusing, but sometimes dangerous. So railroads implemented the standardized time we have today.

episodes.title: #651: The Salmon Taboo
episodes.description: In Japan, salmon used to be garbage fish. Today, it's a delicacy. How one Norwegian with a lot of extra fish changed the tastes of a nation.
episodes.subtitle: People in Japan never ate raw salmon. Then Norway had a salmon surplus—and persuaded Japanese sushi eaters to try something new.
episodes.summary: People in Japan never ate raw salmon. Then Norway had a salmon surplus—and persuaded Japanese sushi eaters to try something new.

episodes.title: #917: Quit Threat!
episodes.description: Sometimes an economy can get so strong the power dynamic between bosses and workers flips: Full employment. Are we there yet?
episodes.subtitle: The unemployment rate in the U.S. is just 3.6%. Many people think we are at, or near, full employment. For the first time in a long while, power is shifting toward workers.
episodes.summary: The unemployment rate in the U.S. is just 3.6%. Many people think we are at, or near, full employment. For the first time in a long while, power is shifting toward workers.

episodes.title: #916: The Whistleblower Whisperer
episodes.description: Jordan Thomas is a lawyer who represents some of Wall Street's biggest whistleblowers. The life that led him here is extraordinary.
episodes.subtitle: Jordan Thomas represents Wall Street whistleblowers in some of the biggest SEC cases against banks. In addition to protecting their secrets, he's also kept some of his own.
episodes.summary: Jordan Thomas represents Wall Street whistleblowers in some of the biggest SEC cases against banks. In addition to protecting their secrets, he's also kept some of his own.

episodes.title: #915: How To Meddle In An Election
episodes.description: In which someone runs a science experiment on an actual election, on actual voters, to test the persuasive power of ethically sketchy methods.
episodes.subtitle: David Goldstein decides to copy Cambridge Analytica and run an experiment on actual voters during the 2017 Alabama special election.
episodes.summary: David Goldstein decides to copy Cambridge Analytica and run an experiment on actual voters during the 2017 Alabama special election.

episodes.title: #914: Trump and Deutsche, A Long Affair
episodes.description: After Donald Trump's companies declared four bankruptcies, several major banks stopped loaning him money. But Deutsche Bank didn't.
episodes.summary: After Donald Trump's companies declared four bankruptcies, several major banks stopped loaning him money. But Deutsche Bank didn't.

episodes.title: #913: Counting The Homeless
episodes.description: From renting hotels to a jobs report-like census in the night, we look at ways communities are helping the homeless.
episodes.summary: From renting hotels to a jobs report-like census in the night, we look at ways communities are helping the homeless.

episodes.title: #407: A Mathematician, The Last Supper, And The Birth Of Accounting
episodes.description: The story of an innovation that changed the way the world works, and of the man who made this innovation possible: Luca Pacioli.
episodes.subtitle: The story of Luca Pacioli, who brought double-entry bookkeeping to the masses,  transforming accounting and businesses around the world.
episodes.summary: The story of Luca Pacioli, who brought double-entry bookkeeping to the masses,  transforming accounting and businesses around the world.

episodes.title: #912: How Uncle Jamie Broke Jeopardy
episodes.description: James Holzhauer took data, probability and a lot of practice with a fake buzzer, and turned it into a fortune on a game show.
episodes.subtitle: How James Holzhauer built on the strategies of Ken Jennings, Roger Craig, and Monica Thieu, to crack the game show Jeopardy.
episodes.summary: How James Holzhauer built on the strategies of Ken Jennings, Roger Craig, and Monica Thieu, to crack the game show Jeopardy.

episodes.title: #911: You Asked The Listener Question Hotline
episodes.description: We answer a bunch of the questions you asked — and even one you *didn't* ask.
episodes.subtitle: What's the cost of being tall? Are people less productive when the weather is bad? Why is vanilla so expensive? Answers to those questions and more.
episodes.summary: What's the cost of being tall? Are people less productive when the weather is bad? Why is vanilla so expensive? Answers to those questions and more.

episodes.title: #910: Economics, Sexism, Data
episodes.description: A young economist holds a mirror up to her field. And starts a national conversation about women in economics.
episodes.subtitle: Alice Wu's undergraduate senior thesis on gender bias on the Econ Job Rumors forum sparked a movement to address sexism in the field of economics.
episodes.summary: Alice Wu's undergraduate senior thesis on gender bias on the Econ Job Rumors forum sparked a movement to address sexism in the field of economics.

episodes.title: #416: Why The Price of Coke Didn't Change For 70 years
episodes.description: For 70 years, the price of a bottle of Coca-Cola stayed a nickel. Why? The answer includes a half a million vending machines and a 7.5 cent coin.
episodes.subtitle: For 70 years, the price of a bottle of Coca-Cola stayed a nickel. Why? The answer includes a half a million vending machines and a 7.5 cent coin.

episodes.title: BONUS INDICATOR: The Calculator That Time Forgot

episodes.title: #881: The Prisoners of the Trade War

It got even more confusing, so today, we call up our man on the ground in Shanghai to make sense of it all. The key to understanding the latest turn in the trade war centers around a giant company most Americans haven't heard of called Huawei. Its rise traces the rise of China's economy and Chinese-style capitalism.
